news_summary: Recent advancements highlight significant improvements in infant health protection, enhanced mRNA vaccine technology, affordable brain data collection methods, and increased worker happiness and productivity with a four-day work week.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès récents mettent en évidence des améliorations significatives dans la protection de la santé des nourrissons, une meilleure technologie des vaccins ARNm, des méthodes abordables de collecte de données sur le cerveau, et une augmentation du bonheur et de la productivité des travailleurs grâce à la semaine de travail de quatre jours.
news_summary_es: Entre los avances más recientes destacan las mejoras significativas en la protección de la salud infantil, la mejora de la tecnología de las vacunas de ARNm, los métodos asequibles de recogida de datos cerebrales y el aumento de la felicidad y la productividad de los trabajadores con una semana laboral de cuatro días.

articles.title: One pregnancy shot slashes baby RSV hospitalizations by 72% — and shields for months
articles.summary: A new UK study shows that vaccinating pregnant women against RSV has led to a staggering 72% drop in hospitalizations of newborns with severe lung infections. By passing virus-fighting antibodies to their babies, vaccinated mothers are helping shield infants during their most vulnerable early months.
articles.content:
Vaccination of pregnant women has been linked to a drop in newborns being admitted to hospital with a serious lung infection, research suggests.

Researchers found the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) vaccine, introduced across the UK in late summer 2024, led to a 72 percent reduction in babies hospitalized with the virus if mothers were vaccinated.

The findings are the first to show the real-world effectiveness of the vaccine in pregnant women in the UK.

Uptake of the jab among pregnant women could help to limit the number of sick babies each winter, reducing hospital pressures, experts say.

RSV is a common virus that causes coughs and colds but can lead to a severe lung infection called bronchiolitis, which can be dangerous in babies, with some requiring admission to intensive care. The virus is the main infectious cause of hospitalization for babies in the UK and globally.

Receiving the vaccine during pregnancy helps to protect both mother and baby. Antibodies - proteins which help to prevent the virus causing severe infection - produced by the mother in response to the vaccine are passed to the fetus, providing protection from severe RSV for the first six months after birth.

The research team, led by the Universities of Edinburgh and Leicester, recruited 537 babies across England and Scotland who had been admitted to hospital with severe respiratory disease in the winter of 2024-2025, the first season of vaccine implementation. 391 of the babies tested positive for RSV.

Mothers of babies who did not have RSV were two times more likely to have received the vaccine before delivery than the mothers of RSV-positive babies - 41 percent compared with 19 percent.

Receiving the vaccine more than 14 days before delivery offered a higher protective effect, with a 72 percent reduction in hospital admissions compared with 58 percent for infants whose mothers were vaccinated at any time before delivery.

Experts recommend getting vaccinated as soon as possible from 28 weeks of pregnancy to provide the best protection, as this allows more time for the mother to generate and pass on protective antibodies to the baby, but the jab can be given up to birth.

Previous research has found that only half of expectant mothers in England and Scotland are currently receiving the RSV vaccine, despite its high success at preventing serious illness.

The findings highlight the importance of raising awareness of the availability and effectiveness of the new vaccine to help protect babies, experts say.

The study is published in the journal The Lancet Child and Adolescent Health. The research collaboration also included the Universities of Bristol, Oxford, Queen's University Belfast, UCL and Imperial College London and 30 hospitals across England and Scotland.

The study was funded by the Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI) Respiratory Syncytial Virus Consortium in Europe (RESCEU), the Wellcome Trust and National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Protection Research Unit in Respiratory Infections, Imperial College London.

Dr Thomas Williams, study lead from the University of Edinburgh's Institute for Regeneration and Repair, and Paediatric Consultant at the Royal Hospital for Children and Young People in Edinburgh, said: "With the availability of an effective RSV vaccine shown to significantly reduce the risk of hospitalization in young infants in the UK, there is an excellent opportunity for pregnant women to get vaccinated and protect themselves and their infants from RSV bronchiolitis this coming winter."

Professor Damian Roland from the Leicester Hospitals and University and Consultant in Paediatric Emergency Medicine, said: "Our work highlights the value of vaccination and in keeping with the treatment to prevention principle of the NHS 10 Year plan we would ask all health care systems to consider how they will optimize the roll out of RSV vaccination for mothers."
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant medical breakthrough where vaccinating pregnant women against RSV reduces hospitalizations of newborns by 72%, protecting vulnerable infants and easing hospital pressures. It highlights successful scientific research, effective public health intervention, and potential for widespread positive impact on infant health.
articles.personality_title: One pregnancy shot cuts baby RSV hospital stays by 72%
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) causes serious lung infections in babies, often leading to hospitalization. Protecting newborns is tricky because their immune systems are still developing.

**What happened**
A new UK study found that vaccinating pregnant women against RSV leads to a 72% drop in hospital admissions for babies with this infection. The vaccine helps mothers pass protective antibodies to their newborns, shielding them during their most vulnerable months.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means fewer babies fall seriously ill and need hospital care. It also eases pressure on healthcare services and offers peace of mind to families.

**What's next step**
Health officials aim to increase vaccination rates among pregnant women to protect more babies. Ongoing monitoring will ensure the vaccine remains effective and safe.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Giving pregnant women an RSV vaccine is a simple and powerful way to keep babies healthier and out of the hospital.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une injection pendant la grossesse réduit les hospitalisations des bébés dues au VRS de 72%
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le virus respiratoire syncytial (VRS) provoque de graves infections pulmonaires chez les bébés, souvent entraînant une hospitalisation. Protéger les nouveau-nés est difficile car leur système immunitaire est encore faible.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une nouvelle étude au Royaume-Uni a révélé que vacciner les femmes enceintes contre le VRS réduit de 72 % les admissions à l'hôpital des bébés atteints par ce virus. Le vaccin permet aux mères de transmettre des anticorps protecteurs à leurs nouveau-nés, les protégeant pendant leurs premiers mois vulnérables.

**Impact**
Cette avancée signifie que moins de bébés tombent gravement malades et ont besoin d'être hospitalisés. Elle allège aussi la pression sur les services de santé et rassure les familles.

**Prochaine étape**
Les autorités sanitaires veulent augmenter le taux de vaccination des femmes enceintes pour protéger davantage de bébés. Une surveillance continue garantira l'efficacité et la sécurité du vaccin.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Vacciner les femmes enceintes contre le VRS est une méthode simple et efficace pour garder les bébés en meilleure santé et hors de l'hôpital.
articles.personality_title_es: Una inyección en el embarazo reduce hospitalizaciones por VRS en bebés en un 72%
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El virus respiratorio sincitial (VRS) causa infecciones pulmonares graves en bebés, que a menudo requieren hospitalización. Proteger a los recién nacidos es difícil porque sus sistemas inmunológicos aún están en desarrollo.

**Qué pasó**
Un nuevo estudio en el Reino Unido encontró que vacunar a las mujeres embarazadas contra el VRS reduce en un 72 % las admisiones hospitalarias de bebés con esta infección. La vacuna ayuda a las madres a transmitir anticuerpos protectores a sus bebés, resguardándolos durante sus meses más vulnerables.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que menos bebés se enferman gravemente y necesitan hospitalización. También alivia la presión sobre los servicios de salud y da tranquilidad a las familias.

**Próximo paso**
Las autoridades sanitarias buscan aumentar la vacunación en mujeres embarazadas para proteger a más bebés. Se continuará monitoreando para asegurar que la vacuna sea segura y efectiva.

**Una frase para recordar**
Vacunar a las mujeres embarazadas contra el VRS es una forma sencilla y poderosa de mantener a los bebés más sanos y fuera del hospital.
articles.image_prompt: A gentle, detailed painting of a glowing, protective shield shaped like a stylized pregnant belly enveloping a small, peaceful baby nestled inside, surrounded by soft, swirling blue and white antibodies symbolizing immunity, set against a calm, natural background with warm, muted earth tones.

articles.title: A tiny chemistry hack just made mRNA vaccines safer, stronger, and smarter
articles.summary: What if mRNA vaccines could be made more powerful and less irritating? Scientists at the University of Pennsylvania have found a way to do just that—by tweaking a key molecule in the vaccine’s delivery system. Using a century-old chemical trick called the Mannich reaction, they added anti-inflammatory phenol groups to the lipids that carry mRNA into cells. The result? A new class of lipids that reduce side effects, boost gene-editing success, fight cancer more effectively, and supercharge vaccines like those for COVID-19. This breakthrough could change how we build the next generation of vaccines and therapies.
articles.content:
As millions of people know firsthand, the most common side effect of mRNA vaccines like the COVID-19 shot is inflammation: soreness, redness and a day or two of malaise. But what if mRNA vaccines could be redesigned to sidestep that response altogether?

In a new paper in Nature Biomedical Engineering, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania show that tweaking the structure of the ionizable lipid, a key component of the lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) that deliver mRNA, not only reduces inflammation but also boosts vaccine effectiveness for preventing or treating a range of diseases, from COVID-19 to cancer.

The key change? Adding phenol groups, chemical compounds with anti-inflammatory properties famously found in foods like olive oil. "By essentially changing the recipe for these lipids, we were able to make them work better with fewer side effects," says Michael J. Mitchell, Associate Professor in Bioengineering (BE) and the paper's senior author. "It's a win-win."

Revising the Recipe

Until now, the ionizable lipids in LNPs -- one of four types of lipids in LNPs, and arguably the most important -- have largely been synthesized using chemical reactions that combine two components into a new molecule, much like two halves of a sandwich coming together.

"Because these processes have been so successful, there hasn't been much effort to look for alternatives," says Ninqiang Gong, a former postdoctoral fellow in the Mitchell Lab and co-first author of the paper.

Looking back at the history of chemistry, the team found an alternative approach: the Mannich reaction, named after the German chemist who discovered it more than a century ago.

Rather than two components, the Mannich reaction combines three precursors, allowing for a greater variety of molecular outcomes. "We were able to create hundreds of new lipids," says Gong.

Exploring that "library" of lipids led the team to discover that adding a phenol group -- a combination of hydrogen and oxygen connected to a ring of carbon molecules -- substantially reduced inflammation.

"It's kind of like the secret sauce," says Gong. "The phenol group not only reduces the side effects associated with LNPs, but improves their efficacy."

The Power of Phenols

Previous studies have found that phenol-containing compounds reduce inflammation by negating the harmful effects of free radicals, molecules with unpaired electrons that can disrupt the body's chemistry.

Too many free radicals and too few antioxidants result in "oxidative stress," which degrades proteins, damages genetic material and can even kill cells.

By checking various markers associated with oxidative stress, the researchers compared the inflammatory effects of LNPs formulated using different lipids.

"The best-performing LNP, which we built using a phenol-containing ionizable lipid produced by the Mannich reaction, actually caused less inflammation," says Emily Han, a doctoral student in BE and co-author of the paper.

Less Inflammation, Higher Performance

With these encouraging signs of reduced inflammation, the researchers next tested whether the new lipids also improved vaccine performance.

Across multiple experiments, C-a16 LNPs, which incorporated the most anti-inflammatory lipid, outperformed LNPs used in on-the-market mRNA technologies.

"Lowering oxidative stress makes it easier for LNPs to do their job," says Dongyoon Kim, a postdoctoral fellow in the Mitchell Lab and co-first author of the paper.

C-a16 LNPs not only produced longer-lasting effects, but also improved the efficacy of gene-editing tools like CRISPR and the potency of vaccines for treating cancer.

Fighting Genetic Disease, Cancer and COVID-19

To test how well the new C-a16 lipids worked in an animal model, the researchers first used them to deliver into cells the gene that makes fireflies glow -- a classic experiment for checking the strength of genetic instructions.

The glow in mice was about 15 times brighter compared to the LNPs used in Onpattro, an FDA-approved treatment for hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR), a rare genetic liver disease.

The C-a16 lipids also helped gene-editing tools like CRISPR do a better job fixing the faulty gene that causes hATTR. In fact, they more than doubled the treatment's effectiveness in a mouse model compared to current delivery methods.

In cancer treatments, the results were just as striking. In an animal model of melanoma, an mRNA cancer treatment delivered with C-a16 lipids shrank tumors three times more effectively than the same treatment delivered with the LNPs used in the COVID-19 vaccines. The new lipids also gave cancer-fighting T cells a boost, helping them recognize and destroy tumor cells more efficiently -- and with less oxidative stress.

Finally, when the team used the C-a16 lipids for preparing COVID-19 mRNA vaccines, the immune response in animal models was five times stronger than with standard formulations.

"By causing less disruption to cellular machinery, the new, phenol-containing lipids can enhance a wide range of LNP applications," says Kim.

Old Chemistry, New Frontiers

Besides investigating the immediate potential of the new lipids to reduce side effects in mRNA vaccines, the researchers look forward to exploring how overlooked chemical processes like the Mannich reaction can unlock new LNP-enhancing recipes.

"We tried applying one reaction discovered a century ago, and found it could drastically improve cutting-edge medical treatments," says Mitchell. "It's exciting to imagine what else remains to be rediscovered."

This study was conducted at the University of Pennsylvania School of Engineering and Applied Science (Penn Engineering) and the Perelman School of Medicine (Penn Medicine), and was supported by a U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH) Director's New Innovator Award (DP2 TR002776), a Burroughs Wellcome Fund Career Award at the Scientific Interface (CASI), a U.S. National Science Foundation CAREER Award (CBET-2145491), the American Cancer Society (RSG-22-122-01-ET), two US National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowships (DGE 1845298, DGE 1845298), a GEM Fellowship, and the NIH/National Cancer Institute Pre-doc to Post-doc Transition Award (F99 CA284294).

Additional co-authors include Rohan Palanki, Qiangqiang Shi, Xuexiang Han, Lulu Xue, Junchao Xu and Christian G. Figueroa-Espada of Penn Engineering; Drew Weissman, Mohamad-Gabriel Alameh, Rakan El-Mayta and Garima Dwivedi of Penn Medicine; and Zilin Meng, Tianyu Luo and Jinghong Li of USTC.
articles.reasoning: This article describes a significant scientific breakthrough that improves mRNA vaccine technology by reducing side effects and enhancing effectiveness. It highlights advances that can benefit treatments for COVID-19, cancer, and genetic diseases, offering hope for better medical therapies and improved public health.
articles.personality_title: A simple chemistry tweak makes mRNA vaccines safer and stronger
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Millions of people have experienced common side effects like soreness and redness after mRNA vaccines, such as those for COVID-19. These vaccines use tiny particles made of fats (lipids) to deliver important instructions (mRNA) into our cells.

**What happened**
Scientists at the University of Pennsylvania used an old chemical method called the Mannich reaction to add special anti-inflammatory parts to the fat molecules that carry the mRNA. This small change created new fat particles that cause less irritation and improve how well the vaccine works.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means mRNA vaccines could become gentler, with fewer side effects, while also being more effective at fighting diseases like COVID-19 and cancer. It also boosts success in gene editing, opening doors for better treatments.

**What's next step**
Researchers will now work on testing these new lipid particles in more vaccines and therapies to confirm their benefits and eventually bring safer, stronger vaccines to more people.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A clever chemistry trick has made mRNA vaccines kinder to the body and more powerful against disease.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une astuce chimique simple rend les vaccins à ARNm plus sûrs et plus efficaces
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des millions de personnes ont ressenti des effets secondaires courants comme des douleurs et des rougeurs après les vaccins à ARNm, comme ceux contre la COVID-19. Ces vaccins utilisent de petites particules grasses (lipides) pour délivrer des instructions importantes (ARNm) dans nos cellules.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des scientifiques de l’Université de Pennsylvanie ont utilisé une méthode chimique ancienne appelée réaction de Mannich pour ajouter des parties anti-inflammatoires aux lipides qui transportent l’ARNm. Ce petit changement a créé de nouvelles particules grasses qui irritent moins et améliorent l’efficacité du vaccin.

**Impact**
Cette découverte signifie que les vaccins à ARNm pourraient devenir plus doux, avec moins d’effets secondaires, tout en étant plus efficaces contre des maladies comme la COVID-19 et le cancer. Elle augmente aussi le succès de l’édition génétique, ouvrant la voie à de meilleurs traitements.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont tester ces nouvelles particules lipidiques dans plus de vaccins et traitements pour confirmer leurs avantages et finalement offrir des vaccins plus sûrs et plus puissants à un plus grand nombre de personnes.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Une astuce chimique intelligente a rendu les vaccins à ARNm plus doux pour le corps et plus forts contre la maladie.
articles.personality_title_es: Un sencillo truco químico hace que las vacunas de ARNm sean más seguras y efectivas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Millones de personas han experimentado efectos secundarios comunes como dolor y enrojecimiento después de las vacunas de ARNm, como las de COVID-19. Estas vacunas usan pequeñas partículas grasas (lípidos) para entregar instrucciones importantes (ARNm) a nuestras células.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos de la Universidad de Pensilvania usaron un método químico antiguo llamado reacción de Mannich para añadir partes antiinflamatorias a los lípidos que llevan el ARNm. Este pequeño cambio creó nuevas partículas grasas que causan menos irritación y mejoran la efectividad de la vacuna.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que las vacunas de ARNm podrían ser más suaves, con menos efectos secundarios, y también más efectivas para combatir enfermedades como COVID-19 y cáncer. Además, mejora el éxito en la edición genética, abriendo puertas a mejores tratamientos.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores probarán estas nuevas partículas lipídicas en más vacunas y terapias para confirmar sus beneficios y llevar vacunas más seguras y fuertes a más personas.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Un ingenioso truco químico ha hecho que las vacunas de ARNm sean más amables con el cuerpo y más poderosas contra las enfermedades.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of glowing molecular structures shaped like tiny lipid nanoparticles gently embracing a shining, stylized mRNA strand, with soft phenol ring patterns subtly woven into the lipids, all floating peacefully above a calm, abstract representation of a glowing cell, using natural tones of soft greens, warm golds, and gentle blues.

articles.title: Budget brainwaves: low-cost system collects brain data outside the lab
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 21 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02303-5Neuroscience initiative in India and Tanzania amasses a trove of high-quality EEG recordings from diverse populations.
articles.content:
Field researchers recorded brain activity from thousands of people in various settings in India and Tanzania.Credit: Sapien Labs Center for Human Brain and Mind

A team of 24 people in India and Tanzania with no previous experience has collected brain-activity recordings from nearly 8,000 people in schools, offices and open-air spaces to create the largest data sets of their kind in Africa and Asia.

The approach, described in eNeuro on 21 July1, could help to expand neuroscience studies in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) — regions that have long been under-represented in human brain research.

The majority of brain studies focus on industrialized, Western populations and involve expensive lab-based imaging tools. Researchers in LMICs often have limited funds, lack trained technicians and have difficulties in recruiting participants.

What’s so special about the human brain? A graphical guide

To address some of these problems, researchers trained non-specialists in each country — 12 people in Tanzania, 12 in India — to record the brain’s electrical activity using portable headsets fitted with 16 electrodes that are placed on the scalp, a technique known as electroencephalography (EEG). Over 30 weeks, the trainees collected data from a wide range of people in their countries with different lifestyles and socio-economic backgrounds, ranging from urban office workers to members of Tanzania’s Hadzabe hunter-gatherer group. Participants also responded to surveys about factors including their medical history, mental health, sleep, diet, lifestyle and use of technology. The study describes recordings from 3,413 people in India and 2,418 people in Tanzania.

EEG recordings “offer the opportunity to look very easily across diverse populations, because it’s a technique that’s portable, it’s cost efficient, it doesn’t take a huge amount of time”, says co-author Tara Thiagarajan, founder and chief scientist at Sapien Labs, a non-profit neuroscience centre based in Arlington, Virginia. The information collected in the study will allow researchers to explore “how the environment impacts the population’s brain physiology, and how diversity of brain physiology relates to different kind of mental outcomes”, she adds.
articles.reasoning: This article highlights a scientific and technological advancement that enables large-scale brain data collection in under-represented, low- and middle-income countries using low-cost, portable EEG technology. It promotes inclusivity in neuroscience research, potentially leading to better understanding of brain health across diverse populations and environments, which is a positive development in medical science and global health equity.
articles.personality_title: Brain data breakthrough: low-cost system captures brain waves beyond labs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many brain studies rely on expensive equipment and controlled labs, often missing voices from diverse communities in lower-income countries.

**What happened**
A group of 24 people in India and Tanzania, without prior neuroscience experience, used affordable, portable EEG devices to record brain activity from almost 8,000 people in schools, workplaces, and outdoor areas.

**Impact**
This new method created the largest collection of brain data in Africa and Asia, bringing brain research to places usually left out. It helps scientists understand brain health across different environments and populations.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to use this rich brain data to explore how environment and culture affect brain function, encouraging more inclusive neuroscience studies worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Affordable, easy-to-use brain scanners are opening doors for global brain research, including communities often left behind.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une percée dans les données cérébrales : un système peu coûteux capte les ondes cérébrales hors des laboratoires
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
De nombreuses études sur le cerveau dépendent d’équipements coûteux et de laboratoires contrôlés, ce qui exclut souvent les communautés diverses dans les pays à faible revenu.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un groupe de 24 personnes en Inde et en Tanzanie, sans expérience en neurosciences, a utilisé des appareils EEG portables et abordables pour enregistrer l’activité cérébrale de près de 8 000 personnes dans des écoles, des lieux de travail et en plein air.

**Impact**
Cette nouvelle méthode a permis de créer la plus grande collection de données cérébrales en Afrique et en Asie, démocratisant la recherche cérébrale dans des endroits habituellement exclus. Elle aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre la santé cérébrale dans différents environnements et populations.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d’utiliser ces riches données cérébrales pour explorer comment l’environnement et la culture influencent le cerveau, encourageant des études en neurosciences plus inclusives dans le monde entier.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Des scanners cérébraux abordables et faciles à utiliser ouvrent la voie à la recherche cérébrale mondiale, incluant les communautés souvent oubliées.
articles.personality_title_es: Avance en datos cerebrales: sistema económico captura ondas cerebrales fuera de laboratorios
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchos estudios cerebrales dependen de equipos costosos y laboratorios controlados, dejando fuera a comunidades diversas en países de bajos ingresos.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de 24 personas en India y Tanzania, sin experiencia previa en neurociencia, usó dispositivos EEG portátiles y económicos para registrar la actividad cerebral de casi 8,000 personas en escuelas, oficinas y espacios al aire libre.

**Impacto**
Este método creó la mayor colección de datos cerebrales en África y Asia, llevando la investigación cerebral a lugares normalmente excluidos. Ayuda a los científicos a comprender la salud cerebral en diferentes entornos y poblaciones.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean usar estos ricos datos cerebrales para explorar cómo el ambiente y la cultura afectan el cerebro, promoviendo estudios de neurociencia más inclusivos en todo el mundo.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Escáneres cerebrales accesibles y fáciles de usar están abriendo puertas para la investigación cerebral global, incluyendo comunidades a menudo olvidadas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of two interconnected, stylized brain-shaped landscapes—one inspired by Indian cultural patterns and the other by Tanzanian natural textures—each embedded with gentle glowing lines representing EEG electrodes, surrounded by diverse symbolic icons of community life such as schoolhouses, office buildings, and open-air market stalls, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones to celebrate accessible brain research across varied environments.

articles.title: Biggest trial of four-day work week finds workers are happier and feel just as productive
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 21 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02295-2Compressing five days of work into four can create stress, but the benefits outweigh the downsides, sprawling study shows.
articles.content:
Workers reported better mental health after they switched to a four-day work week without a reduction in pay. Credit: Getty

Moving to a four-day work week without losing pay leaves employees happier, healthier and higher-performing, according to the largest study of such an intervention so far, encompassing six countries1. The research showed that a six-month trial of working four days a week reduced burnout, increased job satisfaction and improved mental and physical health.

The study’s authors had wondered whether a condensed working week would add to employees’ stress. “When workers want to deliver the same productivity, they might work very rapidly to get the job done, and their well-being might actually worsen,” says lead author Wen Fan, a sociologist at Boston College in Massachusetts. “But that’s not what we found.” Instead, staff members’ stress levels fell.

The study was published today in Nature Human Behaviour.

Pandemic upheaval

Levels of employee stress and burnout soared during the COVID-19 pandemic, leading many workers to quit their jobs, the authors note. The result was large numbers of unfilled positions in some labour markets.

To see whether shorter weeks might be the antidote for poor morale, researchers launched a study of 2,896 individuals at 141 companies in Australia, New Zealand, the United States, Canada, Ireland and the United Kingdom.

Fed up and burnt out: ‘quiet quitting’ hits academia

Before making the shift to reduced hours, each company that opted into the overhaul was given roughly eight weeks to restructure its workflow to maintain productivity at 80% of previous workforce hours, purging time-wasting activities such as unnecessary meetings. Two weeks before the trial started, each employee answered a series of questions to evaluate their well-being, including, “Does your work frustrate you?” and “How would you rate your mental health?” After six months on the new schedule, they revisited the same questions.

Overall, workers felt more satisfied with their job performance and reported better mental health after six months of a shortened work week than before it.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a large, multi-country study showing that a four-day work week improves workers' mental and physical health, reduces burnout, and increases job satisfaction without loss of productivity or pay. This represents a positive development in workplace well-being and could inspire widespread improvements in work-life balance.
articles.personality_title: Four-day work week boosts happiness and keeps productivity steady, study finds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many people feel stressed and tired from long workweeks, often working five days or more. There’s been a growing interest in shorter workweeks, where employees work fewer days but keep their usual pay.

**What happened**
A large study across six countries tested a four-day work week for six months without cutting pay. The workers kept their productivity levels, while feeling happier and healthier overall.

**Impact**
The trial showed clear benefits: less burnout, higher job satisfaction, and better mental and physical health. Employees enjoyed their work more and felt less stressed, proving that working fewer days can improve well-being without hurting performance.

**What's next step**
This promising result encourages more companies to consider trying a four-day work week. Researchers hope the study inspires broader changes in how we work, aiming for healthier, happier workplaces worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Working four days with full pay can make employees happier and healthier without lowering productivity.
articles.personality_title_fr: La semaine de travail de quatre jours améliore le bonheur sans réduire la productivité, selon une étude
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Beaucoup de gens se sentent stressés et fatigués à cause de semaines de travail longues, souvent de cinq jours ou plus. L’idée de réduire les jours de travail tout en gardant le même salaire intéresse de plus en plus.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une grande étude menée dans six pays a testé une semaine de travail de quatre jours pendant six mois sans baisse de salaire. Les travailleurs ont maintenu leur productivité, tout en se sentant plus heureux et en meilleure santé.

**Impact**
L’essai a montré des avantages nets : moins d’épuisement professionnel, une meilleure satisfaction au travail et une meilleure santé mentale et physique. Les employés appréciaient davantage leur travail et étaient moins stressés, prouvant que travailler moins de jours peut améliorer le bien-être sans nuire à la performance.

**Prochaine étape**
Ce résultat encourage plus d’entreprises à envisager la semaine de quatre jours. Les chercheurs espèrent que cette étude inspirera des changements plus larges dans nos façons de travailler, pour des lieux de travail plus sains et plus heureux dans le monde.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Travailler quatre jours avec un salaire complet peut rendre les employés plus heureux et en meilleure santé sans baisser la productivité.
articles.personality_title_es: La semana laboral de cuatro días aumenta la felicidad sin afectar la productividad, según estudio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchas personas se sienten estresadas y cansadas por semanas laborales largas, a menudo de cinco días o más. La idea de reducir los días de trabajo manteniendo el mismo sueldo está ganando interés.

**Qué pasó**
Un gran estudio en seis países probó una semana laboral de cuatro días durante seis meses sin bajar el salario. Los trabajadores mantuvieron su productividad, mientras se sentían más felices y saludables.

**Impacto**
La prueba mostró beneficios claros: menos agotamiento, mayor satisfacción laboral y mejor salud mental y física. Los empleados disfrutaban más su trabajo y estaban menos estresados, demostrando que trabajar menos días puede mejorar el bienestar sin afectar el desempeño.

**Próximo paso**
Este resultado alentador motiva a más empresas a considerar la semana laboral de cuatro días. Los investigadores esperan que el estudio inspire cambios más amplios en la forma de trabajar, buscando lugares de trabajo más saludables y felices en todo el mundo.

**Resumen en una frase**
Trabajar cuatro días con sueldo completo puede hacer a los empleados más felices y saludables sin reducir la productividad.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a cozy office desk with a calendar showing four marked workdays and one free day, surrounded by balanced scales symbolizing equal pay, alongside a glowing heart-shaped clock representing improved mental health and happiness, all rendered in soft, natural tones and gentle lighting.
